habitat_description:
This species is restricted to the Trans-Pecos region of western Texas. Populations are established from the vicinity of Shafter (Presidio County), through the Big Bend area in the Davis and Chisos Mountains, and to the east in the Dolan Falls are of Val Verde County. Most settlements occur at elevations ranging from 1180 to 1712 meters (Ernst and Ernst 2003; Werler and Dixon 2000; Wilson et al. 2000). The Trans-Pecos black headed snake is a secretive and fossorial snake that is generally underground, in crevices, or under some sort of surface cover. Activity is increased at night when it may travel on the surface during the surface is moist conditions are apparent. It burrows in or using soil, decaying logs, and ground litter.

Habitat includes hilly grassland with cholla and juniper, riparian woodland with creosote bush, low hills of arid grassland, and steep-sided rocky canyons with oak, pine, and juniper. Other plant associations include yucca, ocotillo, agace, cacti, and native grasses (Ernst and Ernst 2003; Werler and Dixon 2000).

GP	-Found in plant communities of creosote bush, yucca, cholla, acacia, ocotillo, agave, juniper, pine, oak, and native grasses.
